ratings.comment: Rachel is not very good at public speaking so she often stumbles when talking and makes mistakes when writing example problems on the board. If you talk to her in person she is much better its just that her actual lecture are hard to follow. Her tests are fairly easy though and you shouldn't have much trouble.

Dr. Davis is probably not a good professor if you do not have previous experience with Calculus. She asks the class to do problems without giving examples first. I frequently lost track of what she was doing on the board. Dr. Davis is an alright professor if you have taken Calculus I before, otherwise you should probably find someone else.

Rachel Davis is an AWFUL lecturer. My roommate and I had the same lecture and she has taken Calc 1 before and I haven't and neither of us knew what was going on half the time. She gives example problems during lecture without even showing how to do them in the first place and spends half of time explaining proofs that don't help at all.
Rachel Davis is terrible professor. Lectures were confusing and didn't help much with the material. However, the class is an easy A if you have taken calc in the past.

Dr. Davis is a terrible lecturer. Often managed to confuse students who had already taken the course with muddled proofs and unacknowledged mistakes. Quizzes are simple, exams are difficult but do-able. If you have already taken Calc 1 you will be okay. If you are learning the material for the first time, FIND A DIFFERENT PROF.

I attended the first month of lecture. Rachel was very scattered throughout the lectures, constantly writing on the board from a notebook. I took AP Calc AB in high school, go to the discussions, and do the homework. Lectures aren't necessary if you do that.

Nice/cares about whether or not students understand the material being taught Smart in her field, has difficulties explaining thought processes/how to arrive at answers Lectures are more proving theorems than practicing using the theorems to get answers Way harder to grasp than AP calc AB Takes forever to get into derivatives (too many limits)

Rachel is fairly average. You can tell she is nice and she cares about students. Helpful during office hours. There is just something about lecture that makes it fairly average from my perspective but ineffective teaching for many. We basically just went over definitions, examples, and a few partial proofs here and there.  Not too bad overall.

rachel is a very tough grader, for some proofs in math341, she only gives like 1-2 for total 20 grades. She has very fast teaching speed without care about whether you understand or not. She has quiz every bio week, this is a tough quiz, even though, she has no official final exam, but you have to go to the optional exam in order to have extra.

Well, there isn't much to be said beyond what others have said already. Rachel Davis is not the best professor out there. Her tests are hard but curved. Her lecturing abilities need some work. Use of TA office hours is a must for those who seriously want to get AB or better.

She is nice but her tests are tricky.  It is a proof-based course, but what she writes on the board are definitions, few proof examples copied from textbook and few computational examples . She gives the easiest examples in class and tough questions in quizzes and exams. This does not help me at all. I still have no idea how  to write good proof...

Assigned our only midterm the day after spring break so there was no time to go to office hours to ask questions before the exam. I could have went the week before break but I had other papers and exams to prepare for. No TA, just her and it is horrible.
Great instructor overall. Her lectures were a little bit boring but I still got an A at the end. I don't think it is a hard class (I guess that I am just too smart?)

She will likely improve over the next coming years, but you could tell this was her first year teaching. Lectures were dry but important, since the notes the department sells are certifiably terrible. Make sure you pay attention to in-class examples, since those almost ineluctably end up on exams. Exams were hard, but not intolerable.

Professor Davis is a very nice woman who tries her best to teach a really difficult class. Everyone should get a tutor, study groups and talk to your TA. She may seem awkward when talking in lecture, but she is very helpful in her office hours. She also teaches the hearing impaired class, so go easy on her because she HAS to write everything down.

I went to her lectures for two weeks at the beginning of the semester and just stopped because I didn't get anything out of them. It was a waste of time. She spends most of the time writing everything she says (words and all) on the board. It is annoying and not helpful. My best advice is to find a friend taking the class and struggle through it.

Professor Davis is a really nice person overall, and is always ready to answer questions, however her clear nervousness (we could clearly see her hands shaking, people) and mumbling tone made her quite hard to understand. Although she was happy to answer questions, she seemed frazzled by them. Office hours helped a little for HW.

Davis's lecture were here completing the easiest examples that would not resemble anything that would be on the homework or exams. She also would not follow what the other professors would do, for example making the tests on more units than other professors and not giving any formula sheets and only a single note card on the final.

I would describe Professor Davis as competent. She didn't always give the best lectures, but they were adequate to understand the material. However, during office hours, she was exceptionally nice and helped me learn the underlying concepts behind the calculus. She wasn't the best math instructor I've ever had, but she definitely wasn't the worst.
She is a very smart professor, but not good at verbalizing her teaching. Also, she makes the tests funky so that they are not like the work practiced in homework and discussion.

Super nice, but can't teach. If you can, get into a math tutorial through the Math department: it really helps. That being said, if you want to get an A in this class, you will have to teach yourself or hope that you get a great TA. If possible, do not take Math 222 with her. If it is unavoidable, best of luck.

Had Math 222 at UW Madison. Dr. Davis wasn't bad overall. The course was challenging. She wasn't always clear in explaining, but if you ask her to clarify, she does. My TA wasn't that great. You could tell what material she preferred. She does have tough exams, but if you know the material, it shouldn't be too bad. Lectures are a must.

She means well, and seems like a very nice person, but she's not a very good teacher. It's hard to understand what's important and what's just her rambling on some tangent. It's never clear what she's getting at, and she'll get to the answer to a problem without anyone knowing what was being asked. Poor teacher, but fairly attractive seems nice.

The professor understands the course content well but can not effectively communicate with the students during lecture and office hours.  Material is often not explained well or presented in a manner that makes sense for understanding. For example the professor would present a concept such as Euler's Method with out explain why its useful.

This was Professor Davis's first year teaching, and taught a very difficult Calc 2 curriculum. I took Calc 2 in high school and received a 5 on the exam, but decided to retake the class to adjust. She made the material unnecessarily difficult. I did a lot of learning  from the book outside of class. She definitely improved as she went on though.

Rachel Davis will take half the lecture to write on the board saying what she is about to do is "difficult". She will highlight and take time on unimportant material making it difficult to know what will be on exam. She is not good at explaining anything and will just bring up a new topic without saying anything about it.

Well given that this is her first year teaching, it  sense why she is nervous when she's teaching. Personally, I wouldn't take her again because it is difficult to understand her. However, she does post the notes she writes on the board online which are helpful. Also, she is more approachable in person, so go to her office hours.

To be fair about Professor Davis, this is her first semester as a professor at UW. Despite the bad things written on some of the review, she has improved in her lecture style significantly throughout the class. Wouldn't take her as a lecturer again, but I'm willing to give her the benefit of the doubt.

I think that she has very low self esteem, clueless about everything she writes on the board and doesn't know how to answer questions - she tends to laugh nervously a lot as if on a verge of a mental breakdown. If you want to take a class that will guarantee lectures to be utterly useless, take this one.
Lectures are unclear and she spends more time trying to explain a math concept in words than with examples, doesn't teach things that show up on the test, overall bad teacher

I had taken calc 2 in high school, however, the credits did not transfer so I was forced to retake the class. I got an A in it the first time and Davis still managed to confuse me quite often on topics I had already mastered.
Most learning is done in discussion section.  She does not explain information clearly and often rushes. Sometimes disrespectful to students questions in class.
She does not explain concepts clearly, and that is a huge downfall because it's a math class.

I was thoroughly disappointed with Math 222. The class felt rushed and like their wasn't enough time to cram everything in. I felt ill prepared going into tests as the was not sufficient review of the abundance of material covered. Overall, it caused a tremendous amount of stress and anxiety and was the worst educational experience I've ever had.

To be fair to a lot of the comments I am reading about her, there are a few students in the class with hearing disabilities. So part of the individualized learning plans include the professor writing everything down.

She is new at teaching, so her nervousness really comes out. We waste at least 10 minutes throughout the whole lecture because she has to write everything on the board. Definitely interact a lot with the TA, that's where you'll do a lot of learning for this course. (Michel wears cool shirts!)

She is terrible at relaying information and teaching new subject. Much of the stuff she writes on the board during lecture is useless and does not help the students learn. During her examples the class points out mistakes she makes on a daily basis.
